Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: One consequence is that leaders often generate ideas and strategies without paying attention to their internal process of creation and testing.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Good strategy is built on functional knowledge about what works, what doesn’t, and why. Generally available functional knowledge is essential, but because it is available to all, it can rarely be decisive. The most precious functional knowledge is proprietary, available only to your organization.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: An organization creates pools of proprietary functional knowledge by actively exploring its chosen arena in a process called scientific empiricism.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Good strategy rests on a hard-won base of such knowledge, and any new strategy presents the opportunity to generate it.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: A new strategy is, in the language of science, a hypothesis, and its implementation is an experiment. As results appear, good leaders learn more about what does and doesn’t work and adjust their strategies accordingly.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: know an engineer doesn’t design a bridge that might hold its load. An engineer starts with complexity and crafts certainty. I knew what it was like to be careful, to balance literally thousands of considerations in making a system work. I knew how maddening it was to move from that world to business, where an executive can choose an action based on gut feel and, even a year later, no one will know whether it was a good choice.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: I make a connection between business strategy and the process of science:

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Where does scientific knowledge come from? You know the process. A good scientist pushes to the edge of knowledge and then reaches beyond, forming a conjecture—a hypothesis—about how things work in that unknown territory.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: If the scientist avoids the edge, working with what is already well known and established, life will be comfortable, but there will be neither fame nor honor.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: In the same way, a good business strategy deals with the edge between the known and the unknown. Again, it is competition with others that pushes us to edges of knowledge. Only there are found the opportunities to keep ahead of rivals. There is no avoiding it. That uneasy sense of ambiguity you feel is real. It is the scent of opportunity.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: In science, you first test a new conjecture against known laws and experience. Is the new hypothesis contradicted by basic principles or by the results of past experiments? If the hypothesis survives that test, the scientist has to devise a real-world test—an experiment—to see how well the hypothesis stands up.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Similarly, we test a new strategic insight against well-established principles and against our accumulated knowledge about the business. If it passes those hurdles, we are faced with trying it out and seeing what happens.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: A good strategy is, in the end, a hypothesis about what will work. Not a wild theory, but an educated judgment.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: When engineers use a nice clean deductive system to solve a problem, they call it winding the crank.By this they mean that it may be hard work, but that the nature and quality of the output depends on the machine (the chosen system of deduction), not on the skill of the crank winder.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: If new insights or ideas are not needed, deduction is sufficient. There can be times when results are fine, when no new opportunities seem to have developed and no new risks have appeared. Then, the logical answer to the strategy question is simply “Keep it up, do more of the same.” But in a world of change and flux, “more of the same” is rarely the right answer. In a changing world, a good strategy must have an entrepreneurial component. That is, it must embody some ideas or insights into new combinations of resources for dealing with new risks and opportunities.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: The problem with treating strategy as a crank-winding exercise is that systems of deduction and computation do not produce new interesting ideas,

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Treating strategy like a problem in deduction assumes that anything worth knowing is already known—that only computation is required. Like computation, deduction applies a fixed set of logical rules to a fixed set of known facts.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: The presumption that all important knowledge is already known, or available through consultation with authorities, deadens innovation.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: To generate a strategy, one must put aside the comfort and security of pure deduction and launch into the murkier waters of induction, analogy, judgment, and insight.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: In science one seeks explanations for broad classes of events and phenomena; in business one seeks to understand and predict a more particular situation. But the lack of universality does not make business unscientific. Science is a method, not an outcome, and the basic method of good businesspeople is intense attention to data and to what works.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: An anomaly is a fact that doesn’t fit received wisdom.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: to others, an anomaly marks an opportunity to learn something, perhaps something very valuable. In science, anomalies are the frontier, where the action is.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: “You see, but you do not observe.” The anomalies are not in nature but in the mind of the acute observer, revealed by a comparison between the facts and refined expectations.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: One of the most important resources a business can have is valuable privileged information—that is, knowing something that others do not. There is nothing arcane or illicit about such information—it is generated every day in every operating business. All alert businesspeople can know more about their own customers, their own products, and their own production technology than anyone else in the world.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: once Schultz initiated business operations, he began to accumulate privileged information. As knowledge accumulated, he altered policies.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: “Young man,” said Carnegie, squinting dubiously at the consultant, “if you can tell me something about management that is worth hearing, I will send you a check for ten thousand dollars.”

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: “Mr. Carnegie,” Taylor said, “I would advise you to make a list of the ten most important things you can do. And then, start doing number one.”

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: How could that be of any real use to an experienced businessperson? It was just too simple.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: there was a deeper truth in the story. Carnegie’s benefit was not from the list itself. It came from actually constructing the list.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: The idea that people have goals and automatically chase after them like some kind of homing missile is plain wrong.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: The human mind is finite, its cognitive resources limited.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: When we attend to one set of issues, we lose sight of another.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: people can forget their larger purposes, distracted by the pull of immediate events.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Taylor’s injunction was not simply to make a list of important issues. It was not simply to make a list of things to do. And it wasn’t to make a list of what might be important. Taylor’s assignment was to think through the intersection between what was important and what was actionable.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Carnegie paid because Taylor’s list-making exercise forced him to reflect upon his more fundamental purposes and, in turn, to devise ways of advancing them.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Making a list is a basic tool for overcoming our own cognitive limitations. The list itself counters forgetfulness. The act of making a list forces us to reflect on the relative urgency and importance of issues. And making a list of “things to do, now” rather than “things to worry about” forces us to resolve concerns into actions.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: there is a more fundamental challenge common to all contexts. That is the challenge of working around one’s own cognitive limitations and biases—one’s own myopia. Our own myopia is the obstacle common to all strategic situations.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Being strategic is being less myopic—less shortsighted—than others. You must perceive and take into account what others do not, be they colleagues or rivals. Being less myopic is not the same as pretending you can see the future. You must work with the facts on the ground, not the vague outlines of the distant future. Whether it is insight into industry structures and trends, anticipating the actions and reactions of competitors, insight into your own competencies and resources, or stretching your own thinking to cover more of the bases and resist your own biases, being “strategic” largely means being less myopic than your undeliberative self.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: ask you how you arrived at your recommendations. How did you come up with your response to this assignment?”

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Create-Destroy

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Overcoming quick closure is simple in principle: you look for additional insights and strategies. But, most of the time, when asked to generate more alternatives, people simply add one or two shallow alternatives to their initial insight.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: A new alternative should flow from a reconsideration of the facts of the situation, and it should also address the weaknesses of any already developed alternatives.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: The creation of new higher-quality alternatives requires that one try hard to “destroy” any existing alternatives, exposing their fault lines and internal contradictions. I call this discipline create-destroy.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Trying to destroy your own ideas is not easy or pleasant. It takes mental toughness to pick apart one’s own insights. In my own case, I rely on outside help—I invoke a virtual panel of experts that I carry around in my mind. This panel of experts is a collection of people whose judgments I value. I use an internal mental dialogue with them to both critique my own ideas and stimulate new ones. I try to do this before putting my ideas before others.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Learning from others can be more than simply listening to them, watching them, or reading what they write. When you build your own panel of experts you go one step farther, trying to shape your understanding of their teachings into a virtual personality.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: PRACTICING JUDGMENT

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: In business and politics, and in many aspects of military strategy, most of the important judgments are about people, especially anticipating their actions and reactions.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Judgment begins with knowing yourself, your abilities and biases. Then it extends to knowing other individuals. Much more complex is judgment about small groups and how they will react in response to information or challenges—the domain of many managers, trial lawyers, and platoon leaders.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Finally, there is judgment about large groups of people and markets—the domain of marketing and advertising experts, corporate management, and political leadership.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: To commit to a judgment is to choose an interpretation of which issues are critical and which are not and then to choose an implied action.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: By committing to a judgment—especially a diagnosis—you increase the probability that you will disagree with some of the assessments of others, and thereby increase the chance of learning something.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: The same principle applies to any meeting you attend. What issues do you expect to arise in the meeting? Who will take which position? Privately commit yourself in advance to some judgments about these issues, and you will have daily opportunities to learn, improve, and recalibrate your judgment.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Good strategy grows out of an independent and careful assessment of the situation, harnessing individual insight to carefully crafted purpose. Bad strategy follows the crowd, substituting popular slogans for insights.

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Rumelt, Richard
Highlight: Being independent without being eccentric and doubting without being a curmudgeon are some of the most difficult things a person can do.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: So, what is a system? A system is a set of things—people, cells, molecules, or whatever—interconnected in such a way that they produce their own pattern of behavior over time.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Because of feedback delays within complex systems, by the time a problem becomes apparent it may be unnecessarily difficult to solve.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: A diverse system with multiple pathways and redundancies is more stable and less vulnerable to external shock than a uniform system with little diversity.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: system is more than the sum of its parts. It may exhibit adaptive, dynamic, goal-seeking, self-preserving, and sometimes evolutionary behavior.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Many of the interconnections in systems operate through the flow of information. Information holds systems together and plays a great role in determining how they operate.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The best way to deduce the system’s purpose is to watch for a while to see how the system behaves.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: A stock can be increased by decreasing its outflow rate as well as by increasing its inflow rate.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: stock takes time to change, because flows take time to flow. That’s a vital point, a key to understanding why systems behave as they do. Stocks usually change slowly. They can act as delays, lags, buffers, ballast, and sources of momentum in a system.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Stocks generally change slowly, even when the flows into or out of them change suddenly. Therefore, stocks act as delays or buffers or shock absorbers in systems.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Stocks allow inflows and outflows to be decoupled and to be independent and temporarily out of balance with each other.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: feedback loop is a closed chain of causal connections from a stock, through a set of decisions or rules or physical laws or actions that are dependent on the level of the stock, and back again through a flow to change the stock.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: balancing feedback loop,

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Balancing feedback loops are goal-seeking or stability-seeking. Each tries to keep a stock at a given value or within a range of values. A balancing feedback loop opposes whatever direction of change is imposed on the system.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: reinforcing feedback loop,

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: It generates more input to a stock the more that is already there (and less input the less that is already there). A reinforcing feedback loop enhances whatever direction of change is imposed on it.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Reinforcing feedback loops are self-enhancing, leading to exponential growth or to runaway collapses over time. They are found whenever a stock has the capacity to reinforce or reproduce itself.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The . . . goal of all theory is to make the . . . basic elements as simple and as few as possible without having to surrender the adequate representation of . . . experience.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The information delivered by a feedback loop can only affect future behavior; it can’t deliver the information, and so can’t have an impact fast enough to correct behavior that drove the current feedback.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: your mental model of the system needs to include all the important flows, or you will be surprised by the system’s behavior.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: A stock-maintaining balancing feedback loop must have its goal set appropriately to compensate for draining or inflowing processes that affect that stock. Otherwise, the feedback process will fall short of or exceed the target for the stock.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Every balancing feedback loop has its breakdown point, where other loops pull the stock away from its goal more strongly than it can pull back.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: When one loop dominates another, it has a stronger impact on behavior. Because systems often have several competing feedback loops operating simultaneously, those loops that dominate the system will determine the behavior.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: System dynamics models explore possible futures and ask “what if” questions.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: QUESTIONS FOR TESTING THE VALUE OF A MODEL 1. Are the driving factors likely to unfold this way? 2. If they did, would the system react this way? 3. What is driving the driving factors?

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: You can make a stock grow by decreasing its outflow rate as well as by increasing its inflow rate!

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: A delay in a balancing feedback loop makes a system likely to oscillate.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Delays are pervasive in systems, and they are strong determinants of behavior. Changing the length of a delay may (or may not, depending on the type of delay and the relative lengths of other delays) make a large change in the behavior of a system.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: In physical, exponentially growing systems, there must be at least one reinforcing loop driving the growth and at least one balancing loop constraining the growth, because no physical system can grow forever in a finite environment.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: A quantity growing exponentially toward a constraint or limit reaches that limit in a surprisingly short time.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The trick, as with all the behavioral possibilities of complex systems, is to recognize what structures contain which latent behaviors, and what conditions release those behaviors—and, where possible, to arrange the structures and conditions to reduce the probability of destructive behaviors and to encourage the possibility of beneficial ones.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: When systems work well, we see a kind of harmony in their functioning. Think of a community kicking in to high gear to respond to a storm. People work long hours to help victims, talents and skills emerge; once the emergency is over, life goes back to “normal.”

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Large organizations of all kinds, from corporations to governments, lose their resilience simply because the feedback mechanisms by which they sense and respond to their environment have to travel through too many layers of delay and distortion.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Systems need to be managed not only for productivity or stability, they also need to be managed for resilience—the ability to recover from perturbation, the ability to restore or repair themselves.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: This capacity of a system to make its own structure more complex is called self-organization.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Systems often have the property of self-organization—the ability to structure themselves, to create new structure, to learn, diversify, and complexify. Even complex forms of self-organization may arise from relatively simple organizing rules—or may not.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Complex systems can evolve from simple systems only if there are stable intermediate forms. The resulting complex forms will naturally be hierarchic.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: To be a highly functional system, hierarchy must balance the welfare, freedoms, and responsibilities of the subsystems and total system—there must be enough central control to achieve coordination toward the large system goal, and enough autonomy to keep all subsystems flourishing, functioning, and self-organizing.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Resilience, self-organization, and hierarchy are three of the reasons dynamic systems can work so well. Promoting or managing for these properties of a system can improve its ability to function well over the long term—to be sustainable. But watching how systems behave also can be full of surprises.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Hierarchical systems evolve from the bottom up. The purpose of the upper layers of the hierarchy is to serve the purposes of the lower layers.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The acquisition of knowledge always involves the revelation of ignorance—almost is the revelation of ignorance.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Everything we think we know about the world is a model.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: So are the ways I picture the world in my head—my mental models. None of these is or ever will be the real world.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Our models usually have a strong congruence with the world.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: our models fall far short of representing the world fully.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Everything we think we know about the world is a model. Our models do have a strong congruence with the world. Our models fall far short of representing the real world fully.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: system is a big black box Of which we can’t unlock the locks, And all we can find out about Is what goes in and what comes out. Related by parameters, Permits us, sometimes, to relate An input, output and a state. If this relation’s good and stable Then to predict we may be able,

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Events are the outputs, moment by moment, from the black box of the system.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Like the tip of an iceberg rising above the water, events are the most visible aspect of a larger complex—but not always the most important.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: We are less likely to be surprised if we can see how events accumulate into dynamic patterns of behavior.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The behavior of a system is its performance over time—its growth, stagnation, decline, oscillation, randomness, or evolution.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: When a systems thinker encounters a problem, the first thing he or she does is look for data, time graphs, the history of the system. That’s because long term behavior provides clues to the underlying system structure. And structure is the key to understanding not just what is happening, but why.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: System structure is the source of system behavior. System behavior reveals itself as a series of events over time.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Nonlinearities are important not only because they confound our expectations about the relationship between action and response. They are even more important because they change the relative strengths of feedback loops. They can flip a system from one mode of behavior to another.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Many relationships in systems are nonlinear. Their relative strengths shift in disproportionate amounts as the stocks in the system shift. Nonlinearities in feedback systems produce shifting dominance of loops and many complexities in system behavior.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: There are no separate systems. The world is a continuum. Where to draw a boundary around a system depends on the purpose of the discussion—the questions we want to ask.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Systems analysts often fall into the opposite trap: making boundaries too large.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: boundaries are of our own making, and that they can and should be reconsidered for each new discussion, problem, or purpose.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: At any given time, the input that is most important to a system is the one that is most limiting.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Any physical entity with multiple inputs and outputs is surrounded by layers of limits.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: There always will be limits to growth. They can be self-imposed. If they aren’t, they will be system-imposed.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: I believe we must learn to wait as we learn to create. We have to patiently sow the seeds, assiduously water the earth where they are sown and give the plants the time that is their own. One cannot fool a plant any more than one can fool history.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: When there are long delays in feedback loops, some sort of foresight is essential. To act only when a problem becomes obvious is to miss an important opportunity to solve the problem.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Bounded rationality means that people make quite reasonable decisions based on the information they have. But they don’t have perfect information, especially about more distant parts of the system.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: We live in an exaggerated present—we pay too much attention to recent experience and too little attention to the past, focusing on current events rather than long term behavior.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: We call the system structures that produce such common patterns of problematic behavior archetypes.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Understanding archetypal problem-generating structures is not enough. Putting up with them is impossible. They need to be changed.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: But system traps can be escaped—by recognizing them in advance and not getting caught in them, or by altering the structure—by reformulating goals, by weakening, strengthening, or altering feedback loops, by adding new feedback loops.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Policy resistance comes from the bounded rationalities of the actors in a system, each with his or her (or “its” in the case of an institution) own goals.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Each actor monitors the state of the system with regard to some important variable—income

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: compares that state with his, her, or its goal.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: If there is a discrepancy, each actor does something to correct the situation. Usually the greater the discrepancy between the goal and the actual situation, the more emphatic the action will be.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Harmonization of goals in a system is not always possible, but it’s an worth looking for. It can be found only by letting go of more narrow goals and considering the long term welfare of the entire system.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: THE TRAP: POLICY RESISTANCE When various actors try to pull a system stock toward various goals, the result can be policy resistance. Any new policy, especially if it’s effective, just pulls the stock farther from the goals of other actors and produces additional resistance, with a result that no one likes, but that everyone expends considerable effort in maintaining. THE WAY OUT Let go. Bring in all the actors and use the energy formerly expended on resistance to seek out mutually satisfactory ways for all goals to be realized—or redefinitions of larger and more important goals that everyone can pull toward together.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: THE TRAP: TRAGEDY OF THE COMMONS When there is a commonly shared resource, every user benefits directly from its use, but shares the costs of its abuse with everyone else. Therefore, there is very weak feedback from the condition of the resource to the decisions of the resource users. The consequence is overuse of the resource, eroding it until it becomes unavailable to anyone. THE WAY OUT Educate and exhort the users, so they understand the consequences of abusing the resource. And also restore or strengthen the missing feedback link, either by privatizing the resource so each user feels the direct consequences of its abuse or (since many resources cannot be privatized) by regulating the access of all users to the resource.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: There are two antidotes to eroding goals. One is to keep standards absolute, regardless of performance. Another is to make goals sensitive to the best performances of the past, instead of the worst.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: THE TRAP: DRIFT TO LOW PERFORMANCE Allowing performance standards to be influenced by past performance, especially if there is a negative bias in perceiving past performance, sets up a reinforcing feedback loop of eroding goals that sets a system drifting toward low performance. THE WAY OUT Keep performance standards absolute. Even better, let standards be enhanced by the best actual performances instead of being discouraged by the worst. Use the same structure to set up a drift toward high performance!

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: “I’ll raise you one” is the decision rule that leads to escalation. Escalation comes from a reinforcing loop set up by competing actors trying to get ahead of each other.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Escalation, being a reinforcing feedback loop, builds exponentially. Therefore, it can carry a competition to extremes faster than anyone would believe possible. If nothing is done to break the loop, the process usually ends with one or both of the competitors breaking down.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: THE TRAP: ESCALATION When the state of one stock is determined by trying to surpass the state of another stock—and vice versa—then there is a reinforcing feedback loop carrying the system into an arms race, a wealth race, a smear campaign, escalating loudness, escalating violence. The escalation is exponential and can lead to extremes surprisingly quickly. If nothing is done, the spiral will be stopped by someone’s collapse—because exponential growth cannot go on forever. THE WAY OUT The best way out of this trap is to avoid getting in it. If caught in an escalating system, one can refuse to compete (unilaterally disarm), thereby interrupting the reinforcing loop. Or one can negotiate a new system with balancing loops to control the escalation.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Species and companies sometimes escape competitive exclusion by diversifying. A species can learn or evolve to exploit new resources.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Diversification is not guaranteed, however, especially if the monopolizing firm (or species) has the power to crush all offshoots, or buy them up, or deprive them of the resources they need to stay alive. Diversification doesn’t work as a strategy for the poor.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: THE TRAP: SUCCESS TO THE SUCCESSFUL If the winners of a competition are systematically rewarded with the means to win again, a reinforcing feedback loop is created by which, if it is allowed to proceed uninhibited, the winners eventually take all, while the losers are eliminated. THE WAY OUT Diversification, which allows those who are losing the competition to get out of that game and start another one; strict limitation on the fraction of the pie any one winner may win (antitrust laws); policies that level the playing field, removing some of the advantage of the strongest players or increasing the advantage of the weakest; policies that devise rewards for success that do not bias the next round of competition.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The trouble is that the states created by interventions don’t last. The intoxication wears off. The subsidy is spent. The fertilizer is consumed or washed away.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: If the intervention is a drug, you become addicted. The more you are sucked into an addictive action, the more you are sucked into it again. One definition of addiction used in Alcoholics Anonymous is repeating the same stupid behavior over and over and over, and somehow expecting different results.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Addiction is finding a quick and dirty solution to the symptom of the problem, which prevents or distracts one from the harder and longer-term task of solving the real problem.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Withdrawal means finally confronting the real (and usually much deteriorated) state of the system and taking the actions that the addiction allowed one to put off.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: It’s worth going through the withdrawal to get back to an unaddicted state, but it is far preferable to avoid addiction in the first place.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The problem can be avoided up front by intervening in such a way as to strengthen the ability of the system to shoulder its own burdens.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The secret is to begin not with a heroic takeover, but with a series of questions. • Why are the natural correction mechanisms failing? • How can obstacles to their success be removed? • How can mechanisms for their success be made more effective?

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: THE TRAP: SHIFTING THE BURDEN TO THE INTERVENOR Shifting the burden, dependence, and addiction arise when a solution to a systemic problem reduces (or disguises) the symptoms, but does nothing to solve the underlying problem. Whether it is a substance that dulls one’s perception or a policy that hides the underlying trouble, the drug of choice interferes with the actions that could solve the real problem. If the intervention designed to correct the problem causes the self-maintaining capacity of the original system to atrophy or erode, then a destructive reinforcing feedback loop is set in motion. The system deteriorates; more and more of the solution is then required. The system will become more and more dependent on the intervention and less and less able to maintain its own desired state. THE WAY OUT Again, the best way out of this trap is to avoid getting in. Beware of symptom-relieving or signal-denying policies or practices that don’t really address the problem. Take the focus off short-term relief and put it on long term restructuring.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Rule beating means evasive action to get around the intent of a system’s rules—abiding by the letter, but not the spirit, of the law. Rule beating becomes a problem only when it leads a system into large distortions, unnatural behaviors that would make no sense at all in the absence of the rules. If it gets out of hand, rule beating can cause systems to produce very damaging behavior indeed.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Rule beating that distorts nature, the economy, organizations, and the human spirit can be destructive.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Notice that rule beating produces the appearance of rules being followed.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Rule beating is usually a response of the lower levels in a hierarchy to overrigid, deleterious, unworkable, or ill-defined rules from above.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The way out of the trap, the opportunity, is to understand rule beating as useful feedback, and to revise, improve, rescind, or better explain the rules.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: one of the most powerful ways to influence the behavior of a system is through its purpose or goal. That’s because the goal is the direction-setter of the system, the definer of discrepancies that require action, the indicator of compliance, failure, or success toward which balancing feedback loops work. If the goal is defined badly, if it doesn’t measure what it’s supposed to measure, if it doesn’t reflect the real welfare of the system, then the system can’t possibly produce a desirable result.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: If you define the goal of a society as GNP, that society will do its best to produce GNP. It will not produce welfare, equity, justice, or efficiency unless you define a goal and regularly measure and report the state of welfare, equity, justice, or efficiency.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The world would be a different place if instead of competing to have the highest per capita GNP, nations competed to have the highest per capita stocks of wealth with the lowest throughput, or the lowest infant mortality, or the greatest political freedom, or the cleanest environment, or the smallest gap between the rich and the poor.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Seeking the wrong goal, satisfying the wrong indicator, is a system characteristic almost opposite from rule beating. In rule beating, the system is out to evade an unpopular or badly designed rule, while giving the appearance of obeying it. In seeking the wrong goal, the system obediently follows the rule and produces its specified result—which is not necessarily what anyone actually wants.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: THE TRAP: SEEKING THE WRONG GOAL System behavior is particularly sensitive to the goals of feedback loops. If the goals—the indicators of satisfaction of the rules—are defined inaccurately or incompletely, the system may obediently work to produce a result that is not really intended or wanted. THE WAY OUT Specify indicators and goals that reflect the real welfare of the system. Be especially careful not to confuse effort with result or you will end up with a system that is producing effort, not result.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The world’s leaders are correctly fixated on economic growth as the answer to virtually all problems, but they’re pushing with all their might in the wrong direction.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Parameters become leverage points when they go into ranges that kick off one of the items higher on this list. Interest rates, for example, or birth rates, control the gains around reinforcing feedback loops. System goals are parameters that can make big differences.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: stocks that are big, relative to their flows, are more stable than small ones.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: You can often stabilize a system by increasing the capacity of a buffer.5 But if a buffer is too big, the system gets inflexible. It reacts too slowly. And big buffers of some sorts, such as water reservoirs or inventories, cost a lot to build or maintain.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: A delay in a feedback process is critical relative to rates of change in the stocks that the feedback loop is trying to control. Delays that are too short cause overreaction, “chasing your tail,” oscillations amplified by the jumpiness of the response. Delays that are too long cause damped, sustained, or exploding oscillations, depending on how much too long. Overlong delays in a system with a threshold, a danger point, a range past which irreversible damage can occur, cause overshoot and collapse.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: delays are not often easily changeable. Things take as long as they take.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Any balancing feedback loop needs a goal (the thermostat setting), a monitoring and signaling device to detect deviation from the goal (the thermostat), and a response mechanism (the furnace and/or air conditioner, fans, pumps, pipes, fuel, etc.).

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: One of the big mistakes we make is to strip away these “emergency” response mechanisms because they aren’t often used and they appear to be costly.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The strength of a balancing loop—its ability to keep its appointed stock at or near its goal—depends on the combination of all its parameters and links—the accuracy and rapidity of monitoring, the quickness and power of response, the directness and size of corrective flows. Sometimes there are leverage points here.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The strength of a balancing feedback loop is important relative to the impact it is designed to correct. If the impact increases in strength, the feedbacks have to be strengthened too.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: A balancing feedback loop is self-correcting; a reinforcing feedback loop is self-reinforcing. The more it works, the more it gains power to work some more, driving system behavior in one direction.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Reinforcing feedback loops are sources of growth, explosion, erosion, and collapse in systems.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Missing information flows is one of the most common causes of system malfunction.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: There is a systematic tendency on the part of human beings to avoid accountability for their own decisions. That’s why there are so many missing feedback loops—and why this kind of leverage point is so often popular with the masses, unpopular with the powers that be, and effective, if you can get the powers that be to permit it to happen (or go around them and make it happen anyway).

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The rules of the system define its scope, its boundaries, its degrees of freedom.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: The most stunning thing living systems and some social systems can do is to change themselves utterly by creating whole new structures and behaviors.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Self-organization is basically a matter of an evolutionary raw material—a highly variable stock of information from which to select possible patterns—and a means for experimentation, for selecting and testing new patterns.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: the goal of a system is a leverage point superior to the self-organizing ability of a system.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: If the goal is to bring more and more of the world under the control of one particular central planning system

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: then everything further down the list, physical stocks and flows, feedback loops, information flows, even self-organizing behavior, will be twisted to conform to that goal.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Paradigms are the sources of systems.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: people who have managed to intervene in systems at the level of paradigm have hit a leverage point that totally transforms systems.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: there’s nothing physical or expensive or even slow in the process of paradigm change.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Systems modelers say that we change paradigms by building a model of the system, which takes us outside the system and forces us to see it whole.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: There is yet one leverage point that is even higher than changing a paradigm. That is to keep oneself unattached in the arena of paradigms, to stay flexible, to realize that no paradigm is “true,” that every one, including the one that sweetly shapes your own worldview, is a tremendously limited understanding of an immense and amazing universe that is far beyond human comprehension.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: there is plenty to do, of a different sort of “doing.” The future can’t be predicted, but it can be envisioned and brought lovingly into being. Systems can’t be controlled, but they can be designed and redesigned.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Get the Beat of the System Before you disturb the system in any way, watch how it behaves. If it’s a piece of music or a whitewater rapid or a fluctuation in a commodity price, study its beat.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Expose Your Mental Models to the Light of Day

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: We have to put every one of our assumptions about the system out where others (and we ourselves) can see them.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Our assumptions can no longer slide around (mental models are very slippery), assuming one thing for purposes of one discussion and something else contradictory for purposes of the next discussion.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Honor, Respect, and Distribute Information

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Decision makers can’t respond to information they don’t have, can’t respond accurately to information that is inaccurate, and can’t respond in a timely way to information that is late.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: most of what goes wrong in systems goes wrong because of biased, late, or missing information.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Make Feedback Policies for Feedback Systems

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Go for the Good of the Whole

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Don’t maximize parts of systems or subsystems while ignoring the whole.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Don’t, as Kenneth Boulding once said, go to great trouble to optimize something that never should be done at all.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Listen to the Wisdom of the System

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Aid and encourage the forces and structures that help the system run itself. Notice how many of those forces and structures are at the bottom of the hierarchy. Don’t be an unthinking intervenor and destroy the system’s own self-maintenance capacities. Before you charge in to make things better, pay attention to the value of what’s already there.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Locate Responsibility in the System

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: In analysis, it means looking for the ways the system creates its own behavior. Do pay attention to the triggering events, the outside influences that bring forth one kind of behavior from the system rather than another.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: “Intrinsic responsibility” means that the system is designed to send feedback about the consequences of decision making directly and quickly and compellingly to the decision makers.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Error-embracing is the condition for learning. It means seeking and using—and sharing—information about what went wrong with what you expected or hoped would go right. Both error embracing and living with high levels of uncertainty emphasize our personal as well as societal vulnerability.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: “A thing is right when it tends to preserve the integrity, stability, and beauty of the biotic community. It is wrong when it tends otherwise.”10

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Expand Time Horizons

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Defy the Disciplines

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: In spite of what you majored in, or what the textbooks say, or what you think you’re an expert at, follow a system wherever it leads.

Title: Thinking in Systems
Author: Donella H. Meadows
Highlight: Don’t Erode the Goal of Goodness

Title: Fuera de serie
Author: Malcolm Gladwell
Highlight: para hacerse un lugar en la cumbre. Sus investigaciones sugieren que una vez que un músico ha demostrado capacidad suficiente para ingresar en una academia superior de música, lo que distingue a un intérprete virtuoso de otro mediocre es el esfuerzo que cada uno dedica a practicar. Y eso no es todo: los que están en la misma cumbre no es que trabajen un poco o bastante más que todos los demás. Trabajan mucho… mucho más.

Title: Fuera de serie
Author: Malcolm Gladwell
Highlight: Estas tres cosas—autonomía, complejidad y relación entre esfuerzo y recompensa—son, según conviene la mayoría de la gente, las tres cualidades que tiene que tener un empleo para satisfacer a quien lo desempeña.

Title: Fuera de serie
Author: Malcolm Gladwell
Highlight: «Cuando el hombre trabaja a conciencia, no es perezosa la tierra».

Title: Fuera de serie
Author: Malcolm Gladwell
Highlight: «Trescientos sesenta días al año levántate antes del amanecer y la prosperidad de tu familia llegarás a ver».

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: «El desear una experiencia positiva es una experiencia negativa, mientras que el aceptar una experiencia negativa resulta en una experiencia positiva».

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Pretender evitar el dolor es darle demasiada importancia; sin embargo, si logras que el dolor te importe una mierda, nada podrá detenerte.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Que las cosas te importen una mierda es afrontar, cara a cara, tus más difíciles y atemorizantes retos y, aun así, actuar.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Sutileza número uno. Que algo te importe una mierda no significa ser indiferente; significa sentirse cómodo por ser diferente

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Sutileza número dos. Para que te importe una mierda la adversidad, primero debe importarte algo más importante que la adversidad

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Sutileza número tres. Te des cuenta o no, siempre estás eligiendo qué es importante para ti

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: el dolor y la pérdida son inevitables y deberíamos dejar de resistirnos a ellos.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: «No esperes una vida sin problemas. No existe tal cosa. En vez de eso, espera una existencia llena de buenos problemas»,

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Porque la felicidad requiere lucha, porque nace y crece de los problemas. La dicha no simplemente brota de la tierra como las margaritas y los arcoíris. La plenitud real, seria, duradera y el significado deben ganarse a través de elegir y controlar nuestras luchas.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: No todos somos excepcionales. Resulta que el simple hecho de sentirse bien con uno mismo en realidad no significa nada a menos que tengas una buena razón para sentirte bien contigo mismo.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: la adversidad y el fracaso son, de hecho, útiles e incluso necesarios para convertirse en adultos exitosos y fuertes en términos emocionales.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: nuestros valores determinan la naturaleza de nuestros problemas y la naturaleza de nuestros problemas determina la calidad de nuestras vidas.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Estas actividades son estresantes, arduas y, a veces, desagradables. También requieren ir capeando problema tras problema; sin embargo, son algunos de los momentos más significativos y de las cosas más dichosas que haremos. Involucran dolor, lucha, incluso enfado y desesperación, pero una vez que las hemos logrado, todos pensaremos en ellas con los ojos llenos de lágrimas mientras se las contamos a nuestros nietos.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: «Algún día, en retrospectiva, los años de esfuerzo te parecerán los más hermosos».

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Los buenos valores: 1) se basan en la realidad, 2) son socialmente constructivos, y 3) son inmediatos y controlables.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Hay un simple detalle del que se deriva toda mejora personal y todo crecimiento: la comprensión de que somos, individualmente, responsables de todo en nuestras vidas, sin importar las circunstancias externas.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: tú siempre puedes elegir cómo percibes las cosas, cómo reaccionas ante las cosas, cómo valoras las cosas.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Muchas relaciones en tu vida se construyeron alrededor de los valores que has mantenido, así que en el momento en que los cambies—cuando decidas que estudiar es más importante que irte de fiesta, o que casarte y formar una familia es más importante que el sexo desenfrenado, o que hacer lo que te gusta es más importante que el dinero—, el cambio de tendencia se reflejará en todas tus relaciones y muchas explotarán en tu cara. Eso también es normal e incómodo.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: El crecimiento es un proceso iterativo infinito. Cuando aprendemos algo nuevo, no es que vayamos de «estar equivocados» a «estar en lo cierto». Más bien, vamos de estar equivocados a estar menos equivocados.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Antes de que podamos analizar nuestros valores y nuestras prioridades, y cambiarlos por unos mejores y más sanos, primero debemos perder la certeza de nuestros valores actuales. Debemos arrancarlos intelectualmente, ver nuestros fallos y prejuicios, ver cómo no encajan mucho con el resto del mundo;

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: «El trabajo se expande para llenar el tiempo disponible para su realización».

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Yo digo, no te encuentres. Yo digo, nunca sepas quién eres. Porque eso te mantendrá esforzándote y descubriendo. Y te forzará a mantenerte humilde en tus juicios y a aceptar las diferencias en los demás.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Vale la pena recordar que para que cualquier cambio suceda en tu vida, tienes que estar equivocado respecto a algo.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: vida más feliz en general. Nuestros cambios más radicales de perspectiva por lo regular suceden al final de nuestros peores momentos. Es solo cuando sentimos dolor intenso que estamos dispuestos a analizar nuestros valores y cuestionar por qué parecen estar fallándonos.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: No estés ahí sentado sin más. Haz algo. Las respuestas llegarán después.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: La acción no solo es efecto de la motivación; también es causa de ella.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Cuando el estándar de éxito se convierte en simplemente actuar—cuando cualquier resultado se percibe como progreso e importa, cuando la inspiración se mira como una recompensa más que como un prerrequisito—, nos impulsamos hacia adelante. Nos sentimos libres de fracasar y ese fracaso nos proyecta hacia adelante.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Viajar es una fantástica herramienta de desarrollo personal, porque te libra de los valores de tu cultura y te muestra que otra sociedad puede vivir con valores completamente diferentes y aun así funcionar, y no odiarse entre sí.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: El acto de elegir un valor para ti mismo requiere rechazar valores alternativos.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: La cuestión es la siguiente: a todos nos debe importar algo, para poder valorar algo. Y para valorar ese algo, debemos rechazar lo que es contrario. Para valorar X, debemos rechazar lo que no es X.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: La diferencia entre una relación sana y una enfermiza se reduce a dos cosas: 1) qué proporción de responsabilidad acepta cada persona en la relación, y 2) la disposición de cada persona para rechazar y ser rechazado por su pareja.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Dondequiera que haya una relación sana y amorosa, habrá límites claros entre las dos personas y sus valores, y habrá una avenida abierta para dar y recibir rechazo cuando sea necesario. Cuando digo «límites» me refiero a delinear la responsabilidad de los problemas personales entre dos individuos. La gente en una relación sana con límites bien definidos asumirá la responsabilidad de sus propios valores y problemas, y no asumirá la responsabilidad por los valores y problemas de su pareja.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Cuando tienes áreas turbias de responsabilidad respecto de tus emociones y acciones—zonas en las que no queda claro quién es responsable de qué, de quién es la culpa, por qué estás haciendo lo que estás haciendo—, nunca desarrollas valores sólidos. Tu único valor consiste en hacer feliz a tu pareja. O tu único valor consiste en que tu pareja te haga feliz.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: La gente con límites sólidos comprende que es irracional esperar que dos personas se acoplen al cien por cien y satisfagan cada necesidad mutua. Estas personas comprenden que, de vez en cuando, herirán los sentimientos de los otros, pero que no son ellos quienes determinan cómo se sienten las otras personas. La gente con límites sólidos comprende que una relación sana no implica controlar las emociones del otro, sino que cada uno apoye al otro en su crecimiento individual y para resolver sus propios problemas.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Cuando la confianza se destruye, solo es posible reconstruirla si se dan los siguientes dos pasos: 1) si el destructor de la confianza admite los valores reales que causaron la acción y asume su falta, y 2) si el destructor de la confianza construye un historial sólido de mejoría en su comportamiento a largo plazo. Sin el primer paso, no debería haber un intento de reconciliación en primer lugar. La confianza es como el plato de una vajilla: si lo rompes una vez, con ciertos cuidados y atención lo puedes volver a armar; pero si lo rompes de nuevo, se fracciona en más piezas y ahora requiere más tiempo armarlo otra vez. Si lo rompes más y más veces, al final se hará añicos y será imposible restaurarlo; hay demasiadas piezas rotas y demasiado polvo.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Sí, es probable que la amplitud de experiencias sea necesaria y deseable cuando eres joven, después de todo, debes salir y descubrir por ti mismo aquello en lo que vale la pena involucrarte. Pero es en la profundidad donde se esconde el oro, y tienes que mantenerte comprometido con algo y profundizar en ello para poder encontrarlo. Esto se aplica a las relaciones, la carrera, para construir un gran estilo de vida… para todo.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: El hecho de que te importe una mierda todo es alcanzar un estado casi espiritual de aceptación de la impermanencia de la propia existencia. En este estado, uno es mucho menos proclive a quedarse atrapado en las diferentes formas de sentirse con derecho a todo.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Es importante afrontar la realidad de nuestra propia mortalidad porque elimina por completo todos los valores frágiles, superficiales y mediocres de la vida.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: la felicidad proviene de una sola fuente: que te importe algo más grande que tú mismo, creer que eres un componente que contribuye a una entidad superior, que tu vida es tan solo el proceso secundario de una producción ininteligible mucho mayor.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Tú eres grandioso. Ya lo eres. Aunque te des cuenta o no. Aunque los demás se den cuenta o no. Y no es porque lanzaste una aplicación para iPhone o terminaste un año antes la universidad o te compraste un yate increíble. Estas cosas no definen la grandeza.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
Author: Mark Manson
Highlight: Tú ya eres grandioso porque, ante una confusión interminable y la muerte inminente, continúas eligiendo a qué darle importancia y qué debe importarte una mierda.

Title: El sutil arte de que (casi todo) te importe una mierda
